name: Mushroom 11
description: An award-winning anti-platformer where destruction is the only way to move. Mold yourself into any form by destroying your cells, and traverse a devastated landscape filled with brain-twisting puzzles and bizarre mutations. Are you ready to break the mold?
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP and up Memory: 2 GB RAM Storage: 500 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Every once in a while a game feels entirely self contained and 'perfect'. The last one I can think of is Frozen Synapse and now there's this. It's been frustrating seeing it unreleased for so long, but now seeing the final product I understand the long delays. The visual polish is absolutely amazing. Slowly navigating through its post-apocalyptic wasteland reveals an infinite set of painted vistas. There's just enough visual storytelling to make you wonder of the purpose of the strange blob creature, but no more.  The closes comparison for gameplay is World of Goo with it's analog manipulation of complex physics systems. But otherwise it's entirely original. Nothing out there is quite like it and anything similar that follows will be branded as derivative. It encompasses every inch of the good ideas in this design space and nothing more. No filler.  Some of the later puzzles are a little difficult, but mostly they demand patience. Take a break and come back to it when you're ready to play with physics.
Games as special as Mushroom 11 come along only every so often. This game will be remembered as a salient moment in the history of puzzle platformers. Don't miss it.

absolutely fantastic game. perfect difficulty curve of action & puzzles, never gets too frustrating. atmosphere is beautiful and landscapes is haunting. a level of perfection not often reached by games

Beautifally drawn, amazing music, clever and challenging puzzles with novel mechanics that will make even veteran puzzle/platform gamers stop and think.   The only negative criticism I have for it is that the puzzles that require elongating your shape in a specific way into space are rather tedious with the control scheme and its lack of precision.  9/10

This game is weirdly addictive. The controls, I think, are what makes it both unique and interesting, and immensely frustrating--in the 'I know what to do, and I just need to, dammit. start over and try again' sense. There are plenty of checkpoints spaced out fairly well, so it's somewhat forgiving.   Are you familiar with those squishy tube stress releif toys? The ones that kind of flop out of your hands when you squeeze them, and are made of transparent plastic, and usually filled with colored liquid and sometimes small plastic toys. Imagine you have to push one of those across a rocky, post-apocalyptic landscape, over lava and acid pits, and defeat cyclopean terrors. Imagine that you can only really interact with by pushing it with a fist or a finger. Now you are starting to understand how Mushroom 11 works.   But, like, more complicated than that.

Beautiful, clunky, inventive, and great level designs are probuably the four best words to describe Mushroom 11.  Mushroom 11 looks and sounds great, with exquisite and ambient sounds and music.  Mushroom 11 is clunky, and it'll take you a while to get good with the controlls.  Mushroom 11 is inventive, with so many new and fresh ideas every chapter.  Mushroom 11 has amazing level design, teaching the player and guiding them to the answes the entire time.   This game is amazing, and if you love short but sweet experiences this game is a no brainer.

Nice a unique puzzle platformer. Pefect for playing a few minutes every now and then as frequent checkpoints will allow you to progress even with small amounts of gameplay inbetween other games/things.  Works perfectly in Linux.

“Mushroom 11 is a clever puzzle platformer that involves carefully destroying yourself to slither about the post-apocalyptic world. Exploring the ruins of now extinct mankind while you consume the denizens of the wasteland. Featuring the world’s simplest and most maddening controls.”  Check out the full review on  Youtube .
Amazing and unique platformer game with challenging puzzles and bosses. I totally recommend this!

The game starts off with a lot of potential, and I really enjoyed the first 2 or so levels. But it gets to the point where the game stops using clever puzzles that exploit the clever grow, mold, and shape play style, and exchange it for incredibly tedious platforming.
I'm always looking for games with new mechanics, and this is franky original and fun. Can be frustrating at times.  Look a gameplay video and decide for yourself.  I recommend it.

interesting. would love to see the end of the story but finding it impossible to get past some of the annoying stuff as its just getting me frustrated and im quitting because im not enjoying it if im getting so frustrated.
This is a great game with a very fun movement concept. If you decide to get it, be warned: the later levels can be EXTREMELY rage inducing.
Truly inspired Gameplay, nice Sound and awesome Visuals made even an Platformer Snob like me like this Game. Doesnt Outstay its Welcome, just Frustrating in some Spots.
At last I can experience what it's like to be an amorphous mushroom in a post apocalyptic puzzle riddled world.

brilliant.  I really am enjoying this, more than i thought i would.  From a technical standpoint I find this very interesting. I havent looked, but i would be interested if the devs have done a write up about the tech behind the 'liquid/fluid' physics in this game. I think they have done a great job.  the game look stunning as well.

Other people have said it better, but my experience was mostly tedious. The core mechanic is interesting, but ultimately just too random to be anything more than annoying trying to cross a gap for the 50th time.  Art direction is sound though.
Captivating puzzle platformer. Tricky interesting obstacles, forgiving checkpoints, calming yet eerie atmospheric music and beautiful scenery.

hey guys who made this this game is AMAZING and its my favorite game in steam but there is only 1 problem that is its too short add some chapters, hard mode or challenge mode when you beat game i hope you guys good luck in your game and good uptates

I went into this game expecting to love it... I got tired of it after the first few levels. It's not challenging in a good way, it's just frustrating. A neat idea that could have been executed better. Still, if you can pick it up for cheap, it's not BAD. There's a lot of things to like about it.
Fun mechanic, incredibly frustrating design.

A really good puzzle-adventure game with a very interesting mechanics, but it's so frustrating especially in some harder parts in the game. It isn't caused by the lack of skills but because of this Blob-thing you operate. Sometimes I felt like it was living by itself doing something completly different than I wanted. To be honest, it's a big flaw for those of you who are easily frustrated and imaptient. I finished it after 8 hours with a good dose of satisfaction, but I don't want to go back to it again. All in all, I'm recommending it - difficulty of puzzles is decent, concept of the mechanics is greeat, frustrating experience is my only objection.

This game can be tedious at times you find difficult, but there is a great sense of achievement after you get past that point. The checkpoints are close enough to provide one challenge after another that by themselves is manageable.  The only frustratingly hard parts of this game is trying to get the zero-death runs on world 5, 6 and 7.
This game is not my cup of tea, I recommend it though.  Nice flavour and graphic, inspired and original gameplay. If puzzle platformer ar up your alley give Mushroom11 a try.

It's always risky to try some radically new base mechanic in a platformer game, so I tend to hail anyone who attempts to do so. Enter Mushroom 11, where you can't control your character directly - all you can do is erase a part of it. What you delete will regrow in a few seconds, randomly across the bulk of the fungus. Result: if you persistently delete the right side, the entire bulk will move to the left. And basically that's all. For such an odd mechanic to work, the puzzle design needs to be ultra careful, and this is one area where the game shines - most of the tasks ahead of our hero are well thought-out, rarely very difficult, and the checkpoints are thankfully frequent. The other aspect worth mentioning is the incredible background art and atmosphere.  Mushroom 11 is not without faults, either. One is a direct consequence of the base mechanic - whenever you need to do something with accuracy, you need a lot of luck or a lot of patience. The latter can run out easily when you're shaping your fungus into something elaborate for the umpteenth time, and still end up eg. falling down. The other is more strange - at some points, the game seems to interfere with the physics, forcing a certain solution path. I met this only 2-3 times - one example is the cart ride in level 5 where I found it impossible to keep the fungus in the cart at a certain jump.  Based on the above, there's a little secret to enjoying Musroom 11 - take breaks, even frequent breaks, depending on your skill. There are not many very difficult puzzles in the game (levels 5-7 are more difficult than 1-4, but not dramatically so), but the randomness tends to wear you down after a while, and you'll feel the game is unfair while it's only doing its thing relentlessly. Quit and come back tomorrow, it will feel fresh again.  Untame has done a great job with Mushroom 11 - made a very brave move with the base mechanics, and designed an interesting and visually superb world around it. Definitely recommended.

Overall good puzzle game, but, like others have said, it is very frustrating trying to control the blob and make it do what you want to do. If you are one of those people who like to rage and throw you controller/mouse/keyboard across the room then I won't suggest this game, but if you are up for a challenge then this game will welcome you with open arms. I would however, suggest you get it on sale since I don't feel it is a $15 game
Great visual and sound but its just so god damn hard to control.

This game is so frustrating! Very interesting mechanics that sometimes fight with you but in the end, they make you really think out the platforming puzzles. The artwork is stellar. The story is told from scenery and backgrounds but still feels really interesting.   Pros:  -challenging -Gorgeous Art -New mechanics/Ideas (Original) - Good platforming and puzzles -Each boss is creepy, weird, beautiful, and memorable. -Each level feels unique and thematic  Cons:  -If you hate games like super meat boy where you wanna scream and break stuff this is not your game.
I chose to recommend this game, however, I hesitated very much whether to do it or the opposite. My impressions:   Plus
